bestBHT.bht: Jesus speaks in parables because many people, despite having the opportunity to enter the kingdom of God, fail to do so due to their unfitness. He wants them to see without truly seeing and hear without truly understanding, as their hearts are closed off to the mysteries of the kingdom. It is only given to those who have the capacity to understand to know these mysteries.

Marvin Vincent: Understand (suniwsin). See on understanding, the kindred noun, Mark 12:33.
Archibald T. Robertson: Part of the mystery here explained is how so many people who have the opportunity to enter the kingdom fail to do so because of manifest unfitness.
Jesus speaks in parables because the multitudes see without seeing and hear without hearing. But He also speaks in parable in order that they may see without seeing and hear without hearing.
Only for 'hearing' Luke has 'understand' συνιωσιν, present subjunctive from a late omega form συνιω instead of the -μ verb συνιημ.
John Gill: unto you it is given to know the mysteries of the kingdom of God"
the doctrines of the Gospel are delivered in a parabolical way to others
that seeing they might not see, and hearing, they might not understand

bhtAttempts.bht: Jesus speaks in parables because many people, despite having the opportunity to enter the kingdom of God, fail to do so due to their unfitness. He wants them to see without truly seeing and hear without truly understanding, as their hearts are closed off to the mysteries of the kingdom. It is only given to those who have the capacity to understand to know these mysteries.

The verse speaks of the mysteries of the kingdom of God. Some people fail to enter the kingdom due to their unfitness, which is part of the mystery Jesus explains. He speaks in parables to make people see without truly seeing and hear without truly hearing. Luke uses the word understand instead of hear in this case, emphasizing the importance of grasping the deeper meaning behind Jesus' words. The understanding of these mysteries is a gift given to those who are open to receiving it.

Jesus speaks in parables to reveal the mysteries of the kingdom of God. However, many fail to understand these mysteries due to their unfitness. Through parables, Jesus intends for people to see without truly seeing and hear without truly hearing. It is crucial to grasp the deeper meaning behind his words, as this understanding is a gift given to those who are open to receiving it.

Jesus explains that he speaks in parables to reveal the mysteries of the kingdom of God. The purpose behind speaking in parables is twofold: it exposes the unfitness of those who fail to enter the kingdom, and it also allows people to see and hear without truly perceiving and understanding. The act of understanding these mysteries is a gift bestowed upon those who are receptive to receiving it.

Jesus reveals the mysteries of the kingdom of God through parables, intending to expose the unfitness of those who fail to enter. Speaking in parables allows people to see and hear without truly perceiving and understanding, yet understanding these mysteries is a gift given to those who are receptive.
